The essential feature oi this system consisted in a formula, which the praetor (in irae) prepared after hearing the parties to a suit, and which was remitted to the iudex to regulate his decisiou (iu iudicio). All the formulae generally in use were to be found in the alium Praetoris, and they were multiplied from time to time to suit the exigencies ol particular cases The three parts os the formula were (1) the demonstratio, (statement oi laets, and ground of action), (a) intentio (plaiutifs s claim, and the question lor the decision of the iudex, and which might be modified with the words quantuor aequius ortelius sit, or ex fide barm, binding the iuriex to take the whole circumstances into equitable considem- tion), (3) condemnatio, which gave the iudea power to condemn or acquit the defendant, and which was usually qualibed with a taxatio, restrictrng the amount of damages to be awarded by the iudex to a certain maximum, or adiud i cati o, giving the iudex or arbiter power to adjudicate. We have the text oi a formula given by Gaius (4, 47), in a case where Aulus Agerius sued Numerius Negidius for restoration os a silver table deposited with him and, sailing restitution‚ ior payment ol damages :-

Octauius iudex esto; Quod Aulus Agerius apud Numerium Negidium mensam argenteam deposuit ; qua de re agitur ;

Quidquid ob eam rem N. Negidiunt A. A geria dare facere oportet ex fide bona eius ;

iudex N. Nigidium A. Agerio condemnato, nisi restituat; si nou paret, absolvito.

When the parties had appeared in court, the plaintiff declared his form oi action (ecditio actionis), and applied to the magistrate sor a formula (actionis postulatio). The magistrate or praetor appointed a iudex ior the trial of the case, and delivered to him a iormula determining the question to be decided. The delivery oi the formula cum iudicium mchpitur was the moment ol the litis contestatio, which ended the proceedings in iure. Such formulae were those of Aquilius de dolo malo sor the guidance ol the iudex in a claim for restitution‚ where a fraud had been practised ina sale or some similar proceeding. The formulary system remained in force until the reign os Diocletian, Α. n. 294. See Lord Mackenzie Studia in Roman Lara p. 349 ft, Ramsay Rom. Antiq. p. 278 ft, Gibbou's Roman Enrpire, ch. XLIV.
